nodes.bodyText:
Hm, I think this means the annotation should say @NonNull. If you throw an exception whenever you see a null param, it can't really be null.
(In Java, any object can be null, but the annotation means what it ought to be, for the software to work as designed.)

Can you remove @Nullable from this? Or, possible write it like:
void configure(/* maybe-@NonNull */ JSONObject pluginConfiguration ...)
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -54,14 +54,17 @@
     String getPluginKey();
 
     /**
-     * Configure the plugin with customized configuration object.
+     * Configure the plugin with customized configuration object. A
+     * plugin may or may not require plugin configuration, so see
+     * the documentation for details.
+     *
      * This hook provides a good opportunity to instantiate resources.
      * Any long-lived initialization should take place in {@link #initialize(Context)}, instead.
      * @param pluginConfiguration plugin-specific configuration data
      * @param context An Android Context
      * @throws AmplifyException an error is encountered during configuration.
      */
-    void configure(@NonNull JSONObject pluginConfiguration, @NonNull Context context) throws AmplifyException;
+    void configure(@Nullable JSONObject pluginConfiguration, @NonNull Context context) throws AmplifyException;

nodes.bodyText: It isn't; passing a null value here will result in a StorageException. This should say @NonNull.
